document.docAuthor: Vilnet, Anna A., Borovichev, Eugeny A. & Bakalin, Vadim A.
document.docTitle: Frullania subarctica Vilnet, Borovich. & Bakalin 2014, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Frullania subarctica-a new species of the Frullania tamarisci complex (Frullaniaceae, Marchantiophyta)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Frullania subarctica-a new species of the Frullania tamarisci complex (Frullaniaceae, Marchantiophyta)

subSubSection.paragraph: The species is recognized by moderate size stylus of 5–8 cells long and 1–2 cells wide; disc strongly reduced, up to 3(–5) cells long; ocelli lacking or forming a short line of 2–5(–7) cells long to 1/3 of leaf lobe length; plants red-brown to blackish brown and almost black.

Type: —
Russia . Magadan Province : Ol`skoe Basalt Plateau in upper course of Maltan River , 60°38’46” N , 151°27’25” E ),
1166 m
elev., tundra belt, wet moss-
Sphagnum
tundra on slope, in hollows,
9 August 2011
,
V
.
Bakalin Mag 54-19-11
( holotype VBGI , isotypes KPABG , MHA ). GenBank KC918805 (nrITS1-5.8S-ITS2), KC918789 ( trn L – F )
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Frullania subarctica Vilnet, Borovich. & Bakalin
: 1, 2—part of shoot (in ventral view); 3, 5—both dorsal and ventral lobes of leaves; 4—dorsal lobes of leaves; 6–9—underleaves. Scale bars: 0.2 mm for 1–9. 1–4, 6—Murmansk Province, Melekhin #20639 , 7–9—from Magadan Province, Bakalin #Mag54-19-11 .

subSubSection.paragraph: Plants red-brown to blackish brown and almost black. Leafy shoots (1.1–) 1.2–1.6 mm wide, 1.0– 3.5 cm long, pinnately to bipinnately branched; branches with leaves becoming gradually smaller downward. Leaves conduplicate-trilobed. Dorsal lobes imbricate, apices often incurved, acute or acuminate-apiculate, uniseriate apex of 2–4 cells; cells of leaf apex ± triangular, 8–10(–12) µm, median cells of leaf lobe usually isodiametric or slightly elongated (9–)12–15 × (12–)18-20 µm, usually with thickened walls and coarse trigones; basal leaf cells paler in color (10–)14–16 × (12–)20(–25) µm, often with nodular thickenings; ocelli larger than other cells, ± rounded, (18–)23–28(30) µm in diameter, absent or forming a short line varying from 2–5(–7) cells long to 1/3 of leaf length). Lobule cylindrical to clavate-cylindrical, saccate, with rounded apex, with axis parallel to the stem; stylus small, subulate to filiform, 5–8 cells long and 1(–2) cells wide; disc virtually absent to rarely 3(–5) cells long, very rare with a single tooth of 1-2 cells. Cuticle smooth. Underleaves oblong-quadrate to quadrate-ovate, (0.4–) 0.5–0.6 mm width, with strongly recurved margins, bilobed for 1/3–1/4 (or less) of underleaf length, lobes obtuse to acute, not or slightly auriculate at base. Leaf lobes of lateral branches smaller, commonly with ± well-developed median line of ocelli. Gemmae lacking. [No gametangia and sporophytes seen].

Diagnostic characters: —The species is recognized by moderate in size stylus of 5–8 cells long and 1(–2) cells wide, virtually absent or rarely 3(–5) cells long disk, lacking or a short line of 2–5(–7) cells to ⅓ of leaf length ocelli, red-brown to blackish brown and almost black coloration.

Ecology: —The species mostly occurs in tundra communities on flat surfaces or slopes (from swampy
Sphagnum
tundra to wet dwarf shrub-moss tundra). In the latter habitat the species is characterized by growing as an epibryophyte over wet moss patches. It also grows on north-facing wet cliffs and their crevices in the tundra belt of mountains, where it mostly forms pure mats.

Distribution: —According to the data at hand,
F. subarctica
is an arcto-montane, presumable Asian species with some localities in Europe and North America.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Frullania subarctica Vilnet, Borovich. & Bakalin
: 1—ventral lobe and stylus on stem; 2-4—stylus on stem part of shoot (in ventral view); 5, 9—cells of basal part of dorsal lobe; 6—apices of dorsal lobes; 8—ocellar line in central part of dorsal lobes. Scale bars: 0.2 mm for 1–4; 20 μm for 5–9. 1–3—from Magadan Province, Bakalin #Mag54-19-11 ; 4–9—Murmansk Province, Melechin #20639.
